awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Remotely Operated Avian Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project is the facilitation of more widespread and affordable wildlife research, management, and monitoring through the use of internet-connected devices. Internet-mediated human control of laser hazing devices may provide cost-effective damage reduction in agricultural settings. The research is founded on the ability of lasers to repel a wide variety of birds. Human oversight will benefit from remote operation, allowing the research and development activtities to be conducted at a fraction of the cost of an on-site presence. The immediate problem addressed is avian damage. agricultural losses, predation on sensitive species, and aviation hazards.  Refining and expanding the proposed model may broaden the range of solvable conservation problems. The proposed system seeks to allow one person to simultaneously operate multiple internet connected devices. The creation of reliable, remote management tools may broaden the scope and improve the efficiency of natural resource management. By allowing remote wildland views and providing opportunities for positive intervention, the technology may increase public engagement with the natural world through formal and informal education, improve the understanding of resource protection issues, and enhance public commitment to solving environmental challenges.

The development of a fully integrated, remotely-operable network of internet-connected, artificial intelligence (AI)-enhanced laser devices for repelling pest birds from valuable agricultural assets is proposed. The primary project goal of the project is to make non-lethal pest bird management more effective, easy, and affordable in agricultural, conservation, and commercial settings that are often remote. Phase 1 research and development will cover the creation and initial field testing of a laser array that is remotely controlled by internet connected operators. Phase 1 performance metrics will focus on reliability and ease of use as there are significant operational challenges in various settings (e.g., lack of wi-fi connectivity in wilderness and remote locations, laser safety, etc.).  The project seeks to establish a template for the reliable, remote operation of a wide array of human-controlled devices via internet connections supplemented, where appropriate, with artificial intelligence. This technology may facilitate the wide adoption of more efficient approaches to wildland research, monitoring, and management as the physical presence of the operator will not be required.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Remotely Operated Avian Management

Hardshell Labs, Inc. Phase 1 SBIR

Award #: 2136815    

 

What?s the problem?

Birds cause significant problems for a wide array of human endeavors: sparking fires and power outages for electrical utilities; causing bird strike hazards for aircraft; eating agricultural products; interfering with waste treatment and killing threatened and endangered species.

What did we do?

Building on our familiarity with the laser sensitivity of birds we developed, tested and refined an advanced laser system to chase birds away from areas where they cause problems. Our focus was the Common Raven, arguably the most problematic bird species in the western US and a growing threat to human and wildlife well-being. We developed a remotely operated, internet connected laser allowing an operator to be separate from the place or places to be protected  while still having real-time effects. Using this device, whose development was funded by this National Science Foundation Small Business Innovation Research grant and whose operation was funded through a US Fish and Wildlife Service contract, we reduced raven numbers from hundreds to near zero at a combined sewage treatment plant and composting facility. Overall, we drove over 90% of the ravens away from this favored, food-rich place. The progress we made with managing ravens can fairly easily be expanded to address problems with other species of birds.

 How did we do it?

 We built a chain of connections between an operator at a laptop computer and a camera-equipped, internet-connected laser module far away to monitor ravens and the places they were feeding. The operator observed what was happening in the areas covered by several lasers, ensured human safety, aimed the devices and fired them to frighten birds away. This was a proof-of-concept of truly remote operation of a tool having a positive wildlife management effect.

Weather, especially wind and rain, was hard on our equipment. We partially overcame weatherproofing challenges, but, more importantly, learned from our problems and did extensive design work on proper ruggedizing for the laser units in the field. Our field experience informs further efforts to overcome the challenging environments where we?ll station these devices.

Our interaction with entities likely to benefit from our services included in-depth discussions and cooperation with electric utilities, waste treatment concerns, conservation agencies and dairy and agricultural concerns. The practical knowledge gained, as well as generation of contacts and the deepening of our understanding of the possible markets and use cases, will propel our commercial strategy.

Initial deployment of the devices developed in Phase 1 involved their use in logistically complex settings. Hundreds of laser shots resulted in no hazardous events for onsite workers and a more detailed understanding of the environments where we can effectively use the devices.

Rapid prototyping using 3D-printed elements allowed agile adaptation and timely improvement of lasers in response to lessons learned in the field. In a series of refine-test-improve cycles we moved through multiple configurations of the Remotely Operated Avian Management (ROAM) system, working to reduce the size and complexity of the system, lower its price and increase its effectiveness by upgrading components.

What will it lead to?

Our expected outcomes included highly efficient resource protection: crop defense; improved and expanded threatened and endangered species protection; waste management facility coverage; and bird-aircraft strike hazard reduction at aviation sites. We will continue to work on a flexible business model that provides best fits for each particular problem being addressed, the way the equipment is used, the places it is used and the customers being served. Interviews with utility mangers and linemen, and work with waste treatment operators and dairy owners provided valuable insight on the nature of these markets, their needs and desires.

How will the work benefit others?

Phase 1 progress convinces us that remote actions using ROAM lasers, and similar devices, will provide the following benefits :

  • Improvement of non-lethal pest management techniques will lower conflict between animals and humans and between resource protection interests and animal welfare concerns
  • Reduction of the potential for catastrophic wildfire and other fire related losses of electrical utility equipment by repelling ravens and other birds from nest and perching sites that are vulnerable to hazardous short circuits and subsequent fires
  • Allows citizen conservationists to explore and help protect endangered habitats and species, giving vivid engagement for students and the wider public through connection to remote parts of Earth
  • Remotely operating devices will greatly increase the reach of practical conservation by allowing student and citizen science participation
  • Provision of novel data streams will facilitate more refined understanding of the natural world and resource management options and needs
